study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the inhibitory effect of OZO (Olive Oil) on the growth and spore germination of Alternaria alternata and its ability to inhibit the synthesis of Alternaria toxins in vitro and in orange fruits.
results_summary: OZO showed significant inhibition of fungal growth (29.0 ± 1.2 mm at 20 mg/L) and spore germination (98.8% at 5 mg/mL). It also reduced toxin production (73.4-76% for AOH and AME, 67.1% for TeA) in the PDB medium and prevented toxin biosynthesis in stored orange fruits.
population_specificity: In vitro study (PDB medium) and post-harvest orange fruits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of hydroxytyrosol, tyrosol, and oleocanthal (polyphenols in EVOO) on the proliferation, migration, cell cycle, and antigenic profile of human fibroblasts.
results_summary: The study found that all tested polyphenols significantly increased fibroblast proliferation, with hydroxytyrosol and tyrosol most effective at 10-5 or 10-6 M and oleocanthal at 10-6 and 10-7 M. Enhanced fibronectin and α-actin expression and greater cell migration were observed without cell cycle changes.
population_specificity: Cultured human fibroblasts (CCD-1064Sk cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of olive oil consumption on body fat distribution in adults, comparing its use in cooking or as a supplement to other oils.
results_summary: The study found that olive oil consumption did not significantly alter body fat distribution, though capsule supplementation slightly increased adipose mass and waist circumference while reducing its culinary use. Lean mass decreased with higher doses and longer duration of olive oil intake.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of cold-pressing olives at different maturity stages on olive oil quality, extraction yield, and phenolic content.
results_summary: The new cold-pressing treatment increased oil extraction by 1-2% and boosted total phenols by up to 33%. It also enhanced the phenolic profile of by-products, with hydroxytyrosol concentrations rising by nearly 50%.
population_specificity: Three olive varieties (picual, arbequina, hojiblanca) at different maturity stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether olive oil enhances the antibacterial, anti-adherent, and erosion-protective properties of ellagic acid (EA) in preventive dentistry.
results_summary: Olive oil did not improve the antibacterial or anti-adherent effects of EA but enhanced its erosion-protective properties at pH 3.0, reducing calcium release compared to EA in water.
population_specificity: Six human subjects in an in situ study.
effective_dosage: Not specified (10-minute rinses with EA in water/oil).
study_duration: Short-term (minutes to hours for different assessments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the health benefits of extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) rich in oleocanthal and oleacein versus common olive oil (OO) in individuals with prediabetes and obesity, focusing on inflammatory and oxidative status, weight, glucose handling, and lipid profile.
results_summary: EVOO treatment significantly reduced interferon-γ (inflammatory marker), improved total antioxidant status, decreased lipid and organic peroxides, and led to reductions in weight, BMI, and blood glucose compared to OO. These changes were statistically significant (P < 0.05).
population_specificity: Adults aged 40-65 with obesity (BMI 30-40 kg/m²) and prediabetes (HbA1c 5.7-6.4%).
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants substituted their usual oil with EVOO or OO for food preparation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether topical use of olive oil could reduce symptoms of infantile colic compared to a placebo (liquid paraffin).
results_summary: Olive oil massage reduced crying duration, episodes, and intensity similarly to paraffin oil, with no significant difference between the two groups by the 14th day. Both interventions showed statistically significant improvements in colic symptoms.
population_specificity: Infants aged 1-3 months with infantile colic.
effective_dosage: Abdominal massage with olive oil thrice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the production of hydrochar from alperujo (olive oil byproduct) for enhanced adsorption of pharmaceuticals and develop nitrogen-doped hydrochars to improve adsorption capacity.
results_summary: The study found that hydrochar produced under optimized conditions (higher water/solid ratio, temperature, and longer residence time) had significant adsorption capacity for fluoxetine and cefazolin. Nitrogen-doped hydrochars, especially PEI-HC, showed outstanding adsorption capacities (983.84 mg/g for CFZ and 29.31 mg/g for FLX), with adsorption occurring at different active sites without interference.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (adsorption capacity measured in mg/g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether olive oil could mitigate testicular and spermatological damage caused by sleep deprivation in rats.
results_summary: Olive oil did not improve sperm count or motility in sleep-deprived rats but increased the total number of Sertoli and Leydig cells. No significant changes were observed in seminiferous tubule volumes or other testicular cell types.
population_specificity: Male rats subjected to sleep deprivation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the stabilization of olive oil-in-water emulsions using high-intensity ultrasound (HIUS) with different dairy ingredients (sodium caseinate and whey protein isolate).
results_summary: HIUS treatment improved emulsion stability by increasing the emulsion activity index (EAI) and specific surface area (SSA) while reducing droplet size and creaming index (CI). Continuous HIUS at 50% power with sodium caseinate yielded the highest EAI, while pulsed HIUS at 20% power was least effective. Rheological properties remained unchanged compared to double-homogenized controls.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on emulsions)
effective_dosage: HIUS power levels of 20% and 50% in pulsed or continuous mode for 2 min

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of heating temperature, time, and the addition of virgin olive oil on the bioactive properties and color parameters of tamarillo puree.
results_summary: The study found that increasing heating temperature and time enhanced phenolic content, flavonoids, and antioxidant activity in tamarillo puree with olive oil. The addition of olive oil improved the retention of bioactive compounds and positively influenced color parameters like yellowness, hue angle, and chroma.
population_specificity: Tamarillo puree (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (only temperature and time parameters provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a supplement rich in ω-3 and ω-6 PUFAs and antioxidant vitamins on physical performance and body composition after high-intensity functional training.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Olive Oil's effects.
population_specificity: Nineteen healthy young adults (nine males, ten females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the analgesic, antibacterial, and wound-healing effects of topical ozonized olive oil versus standard post-operative drugs in patients who underwent tooth extraction.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain relief between ozonized olive oil and standard treatment, but ozonized olive oil showed better wound healing outcomes. Both groups improved in pain and healing, but the ozonized olive oil group had superior wound healing.
population_specificity: 200 patients who underwent tooth extraction (exodontia).
effective_dosage: Topical application for three days (specific amount not mentioned).
study_duration: 3 days of intervention, assessed on day 5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hydroxytyrosol-enriched olive oil (OOHT) improves endothelial, arterial, and left ventricular diastolic function in chronic coronary artery syndrome (CCAS) patients by reducing oxidative and inflammatory burden.
results_summary: OOHT improved glycocalyx thickness (PBR), flow-mediated dilation (FMD), coronary flow reserve (CFR), and pulse wave velocity (PWV), while reducing oxidative stress markers (malondialdehyde, oxidized LDL), triglycerides, PCSK9, and CRP levels. No significant effects were observed with placebo.
population_specificity: 30 chronic coronary artery syndrome (CCAS) patients
effective_dosage: 4 capsules/day, each containing 412.5 mg olive oil with 2.5 mg hydroxytyrosol

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of olive oil and flaxseed oil supplementation on blood pressure and inflammatory markers in healthy adults and those at risk of hypertension.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of olive oil supplementation on systolic blood pressure, suggesting limited efficacy in this context. The study concluded that longer-duration, higher-dose, and larger-scale RCTs are needed to better understand its effects.
population_specificity: Normotensive adults and adults at risk of hypertension (pre-hypertensive or stage 1 hypertensive).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review high-level evidence on the cardiovascular and other health effects of olive oil, focusing on consumption amount, frequency, and type.
results_summary: The study found an association between greater olive oil consumption and lower CVD incidence/mortality and stroke risk, though most studies did not differentiate between olive oil types. Current olive oil supplements may not provide sufficient daily doses to match the benefits observed in studies.
population_specificity: Individuals aged ≥55 years old, free of cardiovascular disease at baseline but at high risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the glycemic and insulinemic responses in malnourished type 2 diabetes patients between a diabetes-specific formula containing extra virgin olive oil (AOVE) and a standard formula.
results_summary: The diabetes-specific formula with AOVE resulted in significantly lower glucose and insulin AUC0-t compared to the standard formula, indicating better glycemic and insulinemic control. No differences were observed based on the degree of malnutrition.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes at risk of malnutrition (86.2% moderate, 13.8% severe).
effective_dosage: 200 ml of oral nutritional supplement (specific AOVE content not detailed).
study_duration: One week apart for each formula (crossover design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of omega-3 supplementation versus refined olive oil (placebo) on inflammatory markers in dry eye disease patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in HLA-DR expression between the omega-3 and olive oil groups at 6 or 12 months. Olive oil showed no consistent effect on tear cytokine concentrations, except for temporary differences in IL-6 and IL-8 at 6 months.
population_specificity: Patients with dry eye disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of extra-virgin olive oil (EVOO) in reducing pain and pain intensity in individuals with severe obesity.
results_summary: The study compared EVOO with a traditional Brazilian diet (DieTBra) over 12 weeks, but the abstract does not specify the exact outcomes for EVOO regarding pain reduction.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity (BMI ≥ 35 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of n-3 LCPUFA supplementation versus olive oil on markers of rectal cell proliferation and apoptosis in individuals with a history of colorectal adenomas.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in apoptosis markers between participants taking n-3 LCPUFA and those taking olive oil, suggesting olive oil had neither a proliferative nor pro-apoptotic effect on rectal mucosa.
population_specificity: Individuals with a history of colorectal adenomas.
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether the beneficial effects of olive oil on Metabolic Syndrome (MetS) are related to hydroxytyrosol or oleic acid contents, or their combination, and to evaluate the strength of this effect.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that hydroxytyrosol had no effect on MetS, but olive oil or oleic acid consumption was as effective as other strategies for managing MetS.
population_specificity: Individuals with Metabolic Syndrome (MetS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of extra-virgin olive oil alone and combined with a traditional Brazilian diet on inflammatory markers and glycemic profiles in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and class II/III obesity.
results_summary: The OliveOil+DietBra group showed significantly lower fasting insulin, IL-1α, and adiponectin levels, along with reduced BMI and weight, compared to the olive oil-only group. TNFα levels increased in the OliveOil+DietBra group, while other glycemic parameters remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-64 years with T2DM and class II/III obesity.
effective_dosage: 37.88 ± 12.50 mL/day (olive oil group) and 37.71 ± 12.23 mL/day (OliveOil+DietBra group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of n-3 PUFA supplementation versus olive oil placebo on metabolic syndrome risk in first-episode schizophrenia patients.
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a placebo and did not show significant reductions in metabolic syndrome frequency or its components, unlike the n-3 PUFA group. The study did not highlight any adverse effects or benefits specifically tied to olive oil.
population_specificity: Adult inpatients diagnosed with first-episode schizophrenia.
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (used as placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on ADHD symptoms, using olive oil as a placebo control.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results regarding olive oil, as it was used solely as a placebo in the control group.
population_specificity: 50 children with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cholesterol-lowering and anti-inflammatory effects of a dietary supplement containing olive fruit extract (Olea europaea) in subjects with mild hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a planned evaluation of the supplement's effects on total cholesterol levels and inflammatory biomarkers, but specific results regarding olive oil's effects are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥40 years with mild hypercholesterolemia (total serum cholesterol levels ≥200 and ≤250 mg/dl).
effective_dosage: One capsule (containing flavonoid-rich extract of olive fruit) two times a day, 15 min before the main meal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of omega-3 fatty acid supplements to olive oil placebo capsules in people with cystic fibrosis, focusing on morbidity, mortality, and adverse events.
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a placebo in two studies, but no specific benefits or harms related to olive oil itself were reported. The primary focus was on omega-3 supplementation, with limited evidence suggesting possible benefits but very low-quality data.
population_specificity: Children and adults with cystic fibrosis.
study_duration: Six weeks (in studies using olive oil as placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of olive oil, EPA, and DHA supplementation on serum triglycerides, markers of lipogenesis, and lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in healthy adults.
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a control and showed no significant changes in blood triglycerides, lipogenic index, or LPL activity compared to baseline. The study primarily focused on the differential effects of EPA and DHA, with olive oil serving as a neutral reference.
population_specificity: Young, healthy normolipidemic men and women (n = 89; mean age 21.6 ± 0.23 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (used as a control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of continuing omega-3 supplements versus switching to refined olive oil (placebo) on ocular surface disease outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in ocular surface disease outcomes between patients who continued omega-3 supplements and those who switched to refined olive oil, suggesting similar efficacy. Adverse event rates were also similar between groups.
population_specificity: Patients initially assigned to omega-3 supplements in the DREAM study.
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (used as placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ω-3 supplementation versus olive oil (placebo) on nutritional status, skeletal muscle quality, and chemotherapy toxicity in women with cervical cancer undergoing chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: The control group receiving olive oil showed increased low-radiodensity skeletal muscle index (indicating higher intramuscular fat infiltration) and reduced high-radiodensity skeletal muscle index, unlike the ω-3 group. Olive oil did not demonstrate significant benefits in preserving skeletal muscle quality or reducing chemotherapy toxicity compared to ω-3.
population_specificity: Women diagnosed with cervical cancer undergoing chemoradiotherapy (average age 44.53 ± 8.73).
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (control group received identical-looking capsules, likely matching ω-3 group's 4 capsules/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of n-3 PUFA versus olive oil placebo in reducing symptom severity in first-episode schizophrenia patients and to assess the association between n-3 PUFA's clinical effects and changes in peripheral BDNF levels.
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a placebo and showed no significant increase in plasma BDNF levels compared to the n-3 PUFA group. Changes in BDNF levels in the placebo group did not correlate with symptom improvement.
population_specificity: First-episode schizophrenia patients aged 16-35.
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (used as placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether optimized virgin olive oil (OVOO) and functional olive oil (FOO) provide additional health benefits over standard virgin olive oil (VOO) in reducing oxidative and inflammatory biomarkers.
results_summary: The study found that FOO supplementation resulted in lower urinary 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyguanosine, plasma IL-8, and TNF-α concentrations compared to OVOO, suggesting enhanced anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.
population_specificity: 51 healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of marine n-3 PUFA supplementation versus olive oil on quality of life (QoL) indices in renal transplant recipients.
results_summary: Olive oil (control group) showed no significant improvement in QoL indices compared to marine n-3 PUFAs, with no statistically significant differences in SF-36 scores. The study found no benefit of marine n-3 PUFAs over olive oil in improving QoL post-transplant.
population_specificity: 132 renal transplant recipients
effective_dosage: Equivalent dose to 2.6 g of marine n-3 PUFAs (exact olive oil dosage not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with olive oil, omega-3 fatty acids, and vitamin D for 6 weeks before IVF/ICSI could improve early embryo development markers.
results_summary: The study found that the supplemented group showed accelerated embryo cleavage (CC4), improved synchrony (S3), and higher day 3 KIDScores, indicating enhanced embryo quality, though no difference was observed in CC2.
population_specificity: 111 couples undergoing IVF or IVF-ICSI.
effective_dosage: Additional olive oil and olive oil-based spread (exact amounts not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of acute extra virgin olive oil supplementation on cardiorespiratory coordination (CRC) and performance compared to palm oil and placebo.
results_summary: Olive oil supplementation increased CRC during moderate-intensity walking but did not change performance or other physiological markers. CRC analysis was found to be a sensitive tool for evaluating dietary supplement effects.
population_specificity: 7 participants (specific demographics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) supplementation on DNA methylation changes in leukocytes, alongside exercise and omega-3 PUFA supplementation.
results_summary: EVOO supplementation led to decreased methylation at a specific CpG site of IL6 and reduced DNMT1 mRNA expression compared to omega-3 PUFA. It also showed associations with markers of inflammation and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Eight trained male cyclists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether n-3 fatty acid supplementation (compared to olive oil placebo) reduces cardiovascular risk in patients with diabetes without existing cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: Olive oil as a placebo showed no significant difference in serious vascular events compared to n-3 fatty acids, with similar rates of adverse events and mortality. The study concluded that olive oil did not demonstrate superior or inferior cardiovascular effects in this population.
population_specificity: 15,480 patients with diabetes but no evidence of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.
effective_dosage: 1-g capsules daily (olive oil used as placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of marine n-3 fatty acids versus olive oil (control) on renal graft function in transplant recipients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the change in glomerular filtration rate (mGFR) between the marine n-3 FA group and the olive oil control group (6.7 vs 3.8 mL/min per 1.73 m²). Olive oil served as a neutral control without demonstrating superior or inferior effects on renal function.
population_specificity: Norwegian renal transplant recipients (n=132, with 30 dropouts).
effective_dosage: Daily administration of olive oil (control), exact dosage not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of n-3 LCPUFA supplementation versus olive oil (control) on growth, body composition, and cardiometabolic risk factors in infants by age 5.
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a control and showed no significant differences in growth or cardiometabolic risk factors compared to n-3 LCPUFA, except for boys in the n-3 LCPUFA group who had reduced insulin levels and resistance. No effects were observed in girls.
population_specificity: Infants from birth to 6 months, followed up to 5 years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of n-3 PUFA versus olive oil placebo in improving symptom severity and telomerase levels in first-episode schizophrenia patients.
results_summary: The study found that olive oil was used as a placebo and did not significantly increase telomerase levels compared to n-3 PUFA. Changes in telomerase levels inversely correlated with symptom improvement, but olive oil itself showed no significant clinical effect.
population_specificity: First-episode schizophrenia patients aged 16-35.
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (used as placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between olive oil intake and the risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D), as well as its effects on glycemic control in T2D patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that higher olive oil intake was associated with a 16% reduced risk of T2D and significantly improved glycemic control, including reductions in HbA1c and fasting plasma glucose in T2D patients.
population_specificity: Individuals at risk for or diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of n-3 fatty acid supplementation versus olive oil (control) on offspring SPM levels at birth and 12 years of age.
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a control and did not significantly increase SPM precursors in offspring at birth or sustain effects at 12 years, unlike the n-3 fatty acid group. No adverse effects or significant differences in most SPM levels were noted between the olive oil and n-3 groups.
population_specificity: Ninety-eight atopic pregnant women.
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (used as control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of olive oil as a placebo in comparison to tocotrienol supplementation for bone health in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding olive oil's effects, as it was used as a placebo control in the study.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 45 years and older with at least 1 year after menopause and bone mineral density T-score at the spine and/or hip 2.5 or more below reference values.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether olive oil (as a control) compared to n-3 LCPUFA supplementation during pregnancy influenced offspring telomere length and oxidative stress markers at birth and 12 years of age.
results_summary: Olive oil supplementation did not significantly affect telomere length or oxidative stress markers in offspring at birth or 12 years, with no sustained differences observed compared to the n-3 LCPUFA group.
population_specificity: Pregnant atopic women and their offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on the skeletal protective effects of olives, olive oil, and olive polyphenols against osteoporosis.
results_summary: Animal and cellular studies showed olive oil and polyphenols improved bone health by reducing oxidative stress and inflammation, enhancing osteoblast activity, and decreasing osteoclast formation. Human studies suggested daily olive oil consumption could prevent bone mineral density decline and improve bone turnover markers.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized rats (animal studies), pre-osteoblasts and osteoclast-like cells (cellular studies), and elderly humans (human studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of omega-3 fatty acid supplements to olive oil (as a placebo) in people with cystic fibrosis.
results_summary: Two studies compared omega-3 fatty acids to olive oil for six weeks, but no significant benefits or adverse effects specific to olive oil were reported. Olive oil was used primarily as a control rather than being the focus of efficacy or safety analysis.
population_specificity: Children and adults with cystic fibrosis.
study_duration: 6 weeks (in the two studies comparing omega-3 to olive oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between vitamin E intake (including olive oil) and age-related pathologies, as well as the effectiveness of dietary interventions for preventing vitamin E deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that low intake of vitamin E-rich foods like olive oil correlates with age-related pathologies such as osteoporosis, sarcopenia, and cognitive impairment. Increasing intake of such foods or supplements can help prevent these conditions.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals at risk of vitamin E deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of olive oil (control) versus n-3 PUFA supplementation on disease activity, analgesic use, and inflammatory biomarkers in patients with psoriatic arthritis.
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a control and showed no significant difference in disease activity measures compared to n-3 PUFA. However, the n-3 PUFA group had significantly reduced NSAID and paracetamol use and lower leukotriene B formation.
population_specificity: Patients with established psoriatic arthritis (n=145).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of short-term N-3 supplementation (seal oil) versus placebo (olive oil) on neuromuscular function and physical performance in well-trained athletes.
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a placebo and showed no significant effects on neuromuscular function or performance compared to N-3 supplementation, which had mixed results (some benefits in peripheral neuromuscular function and fatigue reduction, but unclear effects on central neuromuscular function and time trial performance).
population_specificity: Male athletes (n=30), average age 25 years, training approximately 17 hours per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether olive oil supplementation alters DNA methylation in genes involved in PUFA biosynthesis in adult humans.
results_summary: Olive oil altered the methylation of specific CpG loci in FADS2 and ELOVL5 genes, with effects varying by sex. The changes in methylation were associated with transcript levels of these genes.
population_specificity: Renal patients (aged 53 to 63 years) and healthy adults (aged 23 to 30 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of n-3 PUFA supplementation versus olive oil (placebo) on plasma levels of small dense LDL (sdLDL) in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
results_summary: Olive oil (placebo) showed no significant effect on LDL density or sdLDL levels, mirroring the lack of effect observed in the n-3 PUFA group. Triglycerides were reduced in the n-3 PUFA group, but LDL cholesterol and sdLDL patterns remained unchanged in both groups.
population_specificity: ESRD patients with cardiovascular disease on chronic hemodialysis (n=80 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if omega-3 fatty acid supplementation, compared to olive oil (as a placebo), reduces morbidity and mortality in cystic fibrosis patients.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence of benefits from omega-3 supplementation compared to olive oil, with one short-term study showing improved lung function and reduced sputum volume. Olive oil was used as a control and no significant adverse effects were noted, but its direct effects were not the focus.
population_specificity: People with cystic fibrosis
study_duration: 6 weeks (in studies comparing omega-3 to olive oil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of marine n-3 PUFA and olive oil on plasma sCD36 levels in overweight subjects to assess potential cardioprotective mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in plasma sCD36 levels between subjects taking olive oil and those taking n-3 PUFA after six weeks. Olive oil did not show a cardioprotective effect through CD36-dependent mechanisms in this context.
population_specificity: Overweight subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of hybrid palm oil and extra virgin olive oil on plasma lipids related to cardiovascular disease risk factors.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between hybrid palm oil and extra virgin olive oil in their effects on plasma lipids (TC, LDL-C, HDL-C, TAGs). Both oils showed similar reductions in TC and LDL-C, supporting the idea that hybrid palm oil could be considered a tropical equivalent to olive oil.
population_specificity: 160 eligible participants (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 25 mL daily of extra virgin olive oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of simple olive oil versus EGCG-supplemented olive oil on endothelial function, inflammation, and oxidative stress in patients with early atherosclerosis.
results_summary: Olive oil significantly improved endothelial function and reduced inflammatory markers, but there was no significant difference between simple olive oil and EGCG-supplemented olive oil. The study suggests olive oil may play a role in improving endothelial dysfunction and reducing inflammation independently of EGCG.
population_specificity: 82 patients with early atherosclerosis (endothelial dysfunction), 52 completed the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of marine n-3 PUFA and olive oil on the 5-lipoxygenase pathway in overweight subjects.
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a control and showed no significant changes in leukotriene B(4) or 5-HETE formation compared to the n-3 PUFA group. The study found no significant anti-inflammatory effect from olive oil in this context.
population_specificity: Overweight subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if omega-3 fatty acid supplementation, compared to olive oil (used as a placebo), reduces morbidity and mortality in cystic fibrosis patients.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence of benefits from omega-3 supplementation compared to olive oil, with one short-term study showing improved lung function and reduced sputum volume. Olive oil was primarily used as a control and no specific adverse effects or benefits were highlighted for it.
population_specificity: People with cystic fibrosis.
study_duration: Six weeks (in studies comparing omega-3 to olive oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with n-3 PUFA (compared to olive oil placebo) would shorten the QTc interval in haemodialysis patients with cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a placebo and showed no significant difference in shortening the QTc interval compared to n-3 PUFA supplementation. Subgroup analysis within the n-3 PUFA group revealed a shortening effect on QTc, but this was not observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Haemodialysis patients with cardiovascular disease.
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (used as placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of n-3 PUFA supplementation versus olive oil on inflammatory markers and kidney function in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: Olive oil was used as a control and showed no significant changes in inflammatory markers (LTB₄, 5-HETE, LTB₅, 5-HEPE) or kidney function (creatinine clearance, proteinuria) compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Patients with CKD stages 2-5 (n=56).
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether olive oil (used as a control) had any effect on plasma levels of myeloperoxidase (MPO) compared to marine n-3 PUFA supplementation in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in plasma MPO levels after 12 weeks of olive oil supplementation, indicating it had no effect on MPO levels in healthy individuals with low baseline MPO.
population_specificity: Healthy adults with low baseline MPO levels.
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (used as control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether olive oil (used as a placebo) had any effect on reducing atrial fibrillation (AF) compared to omega-3 PUFA in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
results_summary: Olive oil, used as a placebo, showed no significant difference in the primary outcome of AF or any secondary outcomes compared to the omega-3 PUFA group, indicating it had no detectable effect on preventing AF in this context.
population_specificity: Patients (n=108) undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether olive oil (used as a placebo) had any effect on bone mineral density changes in postmenopausal women compared to vitamin K2 supplementation.
results_summary: The study found no statistical differences in bone loss rates between the group receiving olive oil (placebo) and the group receiving vitamin K2. Olive oil was used as an inert control and showed no significant impact on bone health markers.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal Norwegian women aged 50-60, 1-5 years after menopause.
effective_dosage: Same amount as the active treatment (360 µg MK-7), but exact olive oil dosage not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how omega-3 fatty acids protect pancreatic β cells from autoimmune destruction in type 1 diabetes by investigating the role of the ADP-ribosylhydrolase ARH3.
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acids upregulated ARH3 expression, which reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine-induced β-cell apoptosis and chemokine CXCL9 expression, suggesting a protective mechanism against type 1 diabetes development. ARH3 also regulated proteins involved in nuclear, mitochondrial, and endoplasmic reticulum pathways, as well as antigen processing and chemokine signaling.
population_specificity: MIN6 insulin-producing cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary omega-3 fatty acids could mitigate the negative effects of high stocking density on broiler chickens by improving growth performance, nutrient digestibility, and litter quality.
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acids improved body weight gain and feed conversion ratio in high stocking density conditions, enhanced nutrient digestibility, and reduced serum cholesterol levels. They also improved litter quality by reducing nitrogen levels in low stocking density conditions.
population_specificity: One-day-old broiler chickens raised under varying stocking densities.
effective_dosage: Low omega-3 (0.057% of diet) and high omega-3 (0.5% of diet).
study_duration: 40 days (intervention phases: grower phase days 15-24, finisher phase days 25-40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of omega-3 fatty acids (ω3) and vitamin D3 (VitD) supplementation on the nutritional status of newly diagnosed women with breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that combined ω3 and VitD supplementation significantly improved nutritional risk scores, body weight, BMI, blood albumin levels, and daily energy and protein intake compared to baseline and other groups.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed women with breast cancer in the Gaza Strip, Palestine.
effective_dosage: Two daily 300 mg ω3 capsules and one weekly 50,000 IU VitD tablet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of omega-3 fatty acids (ω3) and vitamin D3 (VitD) supplementation on quality of life (QoL) and blood inflammation markers (TNF-α and hsCRP) in newly diagnosed breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The ω3+VitD group showed significant improvements in QoL, including higher functional scores and reduced fatigue, nausea, pain, and appetite loss, as well as significant reductions in hsCRP and TNF-α levels. No significant changes in inflammatory markers were observed with ω3 or VitD alone.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed breast cancer women in the Gaza Strip, Palestine, undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of omega-3 fatty acids supplementation on body composition (lean body mass and fat mass) in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant impact of omega-3 fatty acids supplementation on BMI, fat mass, muscle, or visceral fat, though a near-significant effect on reducing visceral fat was observed (p=0.08).
population_specificity: End-stage renal disease (ESRD) patients on hemodialysis
effective_dosage: 3 grams of omega-3 fatty acids daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical effects of Omega-3 PUFAs as monotherapy in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The Omega-3 PUFAs group showed significantly lower depression scores at weeks 4, 6, 8, and 12 compared to placebo, with modest but non-significant improvements in remission and response rates by week 12.
population_specificity: 60 patients with MDD.
effective_dosage: 3.2 g of EPA and DHA per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 1 g of omega-3 fatty acids daily could improve vision-targeted health-related quality of life in adults with diabetes, as measured by the NEI-VFQ-25 questionnaire.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of omega-3 fatty acids on composite or subdomain scores from the NEI-VFQ-25 over 7.5 years, indicating no measurable improvement in vision-related quality of life.
population_specificity: 15,480 UK adults with diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of daily supplementation with n-3 PUFA versus olive oil on inflammatory markers in patients with chronic heart failure.
results_summary: Olive oil supplementation did not significantly affect plasma levels of sCAMs or hs-CRP in patients with CHF. No significant changes in inflammatory markers were observed compared to the n-3 PUFA group.
population_specificity: 138 patients with NYHA class II-III chronic heart failure.
effective_dosage: Not specified for olive oil (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of marine n-3 PUFA supplementation versus olive oil (control) on serum levels of MMP-9, TIMP-1, and alpha2-macroglobulin in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant changes in serum levels of MMP-9, TIMP-1, and alpha2-macroglobulin in the olive oil group, indicating no effect on these biomarkers. Olive oil served as a neutral control, showing no impact compared to marine n-3 PUFA supplementation.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation in people with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found very uncertain effects of omega-3 fatty acids on quality of life, walking distance, ankle-brachial index, and clinical outcomes like revascularization or amputation. Adverse events were slightly higher in the intervention group but not significantly different.
population_specificity: People with intermittent claudication due to peripheral artery disease.
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from four weeks to six years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether omega-3 PUFAs could prevent the transition to psychosis in ultra-high-risk (UHR) individuals for first-episode psychosis (FEP).
results_summary: The study found no beneficial effect of omega-3 PUFAs compared to placebo in preventing psychosis transition or reducing symptom severity. Dropout rates and serious adverse events were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults aged 13-20 years at ultra-high risk for first-episode psychosis.
study_duration: 6 months of treatment, followed by 18 months of post-treatment follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of omega-3 fatty acids as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (SRP) versus SRP alone in treating periodontitis.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 fatty acids as an adjunct to SRP improved periodontal parameters, with significant reductions in plaque and bleeding indices, though gingival index and probing depth showed no significant difference between groups. The combined treatment enhanced both soft and hard tissue outcomes.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with Stage II Grade B periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), an Omega-3 fatty acid, could protect human primary chondrocytes and cartilage explants from mechanical overload-induced damage and prevent post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA).
results_summary: EPA treatment improved chondrocyte viability, reduced mechanical sensitivity, decreased apoptosis and oxidative stress, and sustained collagen type II alpha expression in cartilage explants subjected to trauma. The findings suggest EPA may inhibit Piezo1 activation and mitigate damage from mechanical overload.
population_specificity: Human primary chondrocytes (HPCs) and cartilage explants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and systematize data from preclinical studies on the effects of omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids in experimentally induced periodontitis.
results_summary: Omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids may decrease the progression of periodontitis, reduce alveolar bone loss, lower pro-inflammatory response, and inhibit osteoclasts, though most studies had low to moderate quality and significant risk of bias.
population_specificity: Preclinical in vivo experimental studies (animal models) with induced periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an omega-3 fatty acid-enriched diet could reverse depression-like behavior and myelin-related changes in rat offspring caused by maternal high-fat diet exposure.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation reversed depressive-like behavior and normalized myelin-related protein expression and oligodendrocyte populations in the prefrontal cortex, with stronger effects in males than females.
population_specificity: Rat offspring exposed to maternal high-fat diet during pregnancy and lactation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (60% energy from fat in maternal diet; omega-3 diet composition not detailed).
study_duration: From post-weaning until adulthood (63rd day of life).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of EPA and DHA, in combination with antiplatelet drugs, on platelet aggregation and membrane expression of P-selectin and αIIbβ3.
results_summary: Both DHA and EPA showed dose-dependent inhibition of platelet aggregation induced by AA, ADP, and TRAP-6. They enhanced the inhibitory effects of certain antiplatelet drugs (ASA, triflusal, ticagrelor) but did not improve vorapaxar's effects. Both fatty acids inhibited αIIbβ3 membrane expression but had no effect on P-selectin expression.
population_specificity: In vitro study (platelet aggregation assays), not a specific human population.
interactions: Enhanced inhibitory effects when combined with ASA, triflusal, and ticagrelor; no improvement with vorapaxar.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of omega-3 supplementation in treating chronic kidney disease-associated pruritus (CKD-aP).
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acids significantly reduced the severity of CKD-aP at the end of treatment and from baseline, though the risk reduction for CKD-aP was not statistically significant. The supplementation was deemed effective and safe.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage renal disease suffering from CKD-aP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of omega-3 PUFAs in preventing and reversing metabolic complications in women with PCOS, focusing on their cardioprotective and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 PUFAs improved components of metabolic syndrome in women with PCOS, demonstrating hypotriglyceridemic, cardioprotective, and anti-inflammatory benefits. Clinical trials supported their efficacy in alleviating metabolic complications.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) of reproductive age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (LC ω-3 PUFAs) supplementation could mitigate neuroaxonal injury, as measured by Nf-L concentrations, in athletes exposed to repetitive subconcussive head impacts.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that LC ω-3 PUFA supplementation significantly reduced Nf-L concentrations by postseason compared to placebo, though the midseason reduction was not statistically significant. The results suggest potential neuroprotective benefits for contact sport athletes.
population_specificity: Collegiate American football players (n = 179).
study_duration: From baseline to midseason and postseason (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 fatty acids could mitigate tamoxifen-induced testicular dysfunction in male Wistar rats.
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acids ameliorated tamoxifen-induced testicular dysfunction by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis, while improving sperm quality and hormonal balance.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Cucumaria frondosa viscera as a natural source of omega-3 fatty acids using supercritical carbon dioxide extraction and compare its efficiency to traditional solvent-based methods.
results_summary: The study found that supercritical CO2 extraction yielded higher fatty acid content (16.30 g/100 g dried samples) compared to the Bligh and Dyer method (9.02 g/100 g). Freeze-drying and ethanol-soaking significantly enhanced fatty acid recovery, with freeze-drying achieving nearly 100% recovery.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using sea cucumber viscera).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (extraction conditions: 75 °C, 45 MPa, 20 min static, 30 min dynamic extraction, 2:1 ethanol to feedstock ratio).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) as an anti-inflammatory supplement on hs-CRP levels in acute myocardial infarction (MI) patients.
results_summary: Omega-3 PUFAs significantly reduced hs-CRP levels more than placebo in acute MI patients after 30 days of treatment, though other lipid parameters decreased similarly in both groups. The study suggests omega-3 PUFAs may help inhibit inflammation in early-stage acute MI.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with acute myocardial infarction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects of omega-3 fatty acids on gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) at cellular and animal levels, focusing on anti-inflammatory and metabolic outcomes.
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acids promoted anti-inflammatory M2 macrophage transformation, reduced hepatocyte lipid synthesis, improved hepatic function, and lowered fasting blood glucose, glucose tolerance, and insulin tolerance in GDM mice. They also reduced liver fibrosis and improved offspring outcomes, including reduced birth mortality and better glycemic stabilization.
population_specificity: Pregnant mice with GDM and their offspring, as well as HepG2 hepatocyte cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between dietary Omega-3 fatty acid intake and accelerated phenotypic aging (PhenoAgeAccel), assessing its potential to slow biological aging.
results_summary: The study found a significant negative correlation between Omega-3 intake and PhenoAgeAccel, indicating that higher intake slows accelerated aging, with a threshold effect stabilizing at 1.103 grams/day. Demographic factors like gender, age, race, and hypertension influenced this relationship.
population_specificity: 20,337 adult participants from the NHANES (1999-2018), a nationally representative sample.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms by which Omega-3 PUFAs benefit the cardiovascular system and assess their effects in heart failure patients.
results_summary: The study highlights Omega-3 PUFAs' positive cardiovascular effects, supported by observational and treatment studies, particularly in heart failure patients.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular disease, including coronary artery disease and heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 supplementation as an adjunct to nonsurgical periodontal treatment improves clinical parameters in smoker and non-smoker periodontitis patients.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation significantly improved clinical parameters (CAL, PD, GI, BOP%) in both smokers and non-smokers, with greater reductions in PD and CAL for moderately deep and deep pockets compared to groups not taking omega-3. The benefits were observed at 1 and 3 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: 80 periodontitis patients (40 smokers and 40 non-smokers) who were systemically healthy.
effective_dosage: 1320 mg Omega-3 capsule (640 mg EPA, 480 mg DHA) once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 fatty acids, as a dietary supplement alongside scaling and root planing (SRP), could improve clinical and immunological outcomes in chronic periodontitis patients compared to SRP alone.
results_summary: The study found that both groups (SRP + omega-3 and SRP alone) showed significant improvements in clinical and immunological parameters at 6 months, but the omega-3 group demonstrated more favorable and statistically significant results.
population_specificity: 60 patients with chronic periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing EPA/DHA levels through a Mediterranean diet and algae-derived omega-3 supplementation could alleviate acne severity in patients with deficits.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 supplementation significantly increased EPA/DHA levels, reduced acne lesions, and improved quality of life, particularly in patients with acne papulopustulosa. Dietary triggers like cow's milk were identified, and compliance was high with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: 60 acne patients (23 with acne comedonica, 37 with acne papulopustulosa) not on prescription medication.
effective_dosage: 600 mg DHA/300 mg EPA (weeks 1-8), then 800 mg DHA/400 mg EPA (weeks 8-16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic roles of omega-3 fatty acids, their limitations, and modern encapsulation strategies to enhance their effectiveness in drug delivery systems.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 fatty acids offer diverse health benefits, including cardiovascular and cognitive support, but face challenges like oxidation and low bioavailability. Nanoparticle encapsulation, particularly using metal-organic framework nanoparticles, shows promise in improving stability and bioavailability.
population_specificity: Not specified (general health benefits discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify differentially expressed genes in the hypothalamus of lambs born to dams supplemented with omega-3 fatty acids or methionine during late gestation, to understand sexually dimorphic effects on offspring growth.
results_summary: The study found minimal differences in gene expression between sexes for omega-3 fatty acid supplementation (CONT vs. FAS), but significant differences for methionine supplementation (CONT vs. METS), with over 100 genes upregulated in female lambs. The results suggest omega-3 fatty acids had limited impact compared to methionine on hypothalamic gene expression related to growth and development.
population_specificity: Sheep (ewes and their offspring)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation (EPA alone or EPA + DHA) on cardiovascular outcomes, including coronary revascularization, myocardial infarction, stroke, heart failure, unstable angina, and cardiovascular death.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation reduced the risk of revascularization, myocardial infarction, and cardiovascular death, with EPA alone showing greater benefits than EPA + DHA. The effects persisted even in participants on statin therapy.
population_specificity: 134,144 participants in primary and secondary cardiovascular prevention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms of B(a)P-induced lung carcinogenesis and the potential role of dietary phytochemicals in chemoprevention.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that dietary phytochemicals show promise in ameliorating lung cancer pathophysiological changes and supplementing conventional treatments with fewer side effects, though specific efficacy data are not detailed.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to B(a)P-induced lung cancer (preclinical model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tart cherry juice concentrate increases urinary melatonin levels and improves sleep quality in healthy adults.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice significantly increased total melatonin content and improved sleep duration and efficiency, though no changes in melatonin circadian rhythm timing were observed.
population_specificity: 20 healthy adult volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of dietary antioxidant phytochemicals in mitigating symptoms of eccentric exercise-induced muscle damage.
results_summary: The study suggests that dietary antioxidant phytochemicals may help attenuate symptoms related to muscle damage from eccentric exercise, though inconsistencies exist regarding oxidative stress and inflammation markers. Effectiveness appears dependent on phytochemical properties and food matrix, with methodological issues potentially affecting interpretation.
population_specificity: Individuals engaging in unaccustomed eccentric exercise (e.g., weight lowering, downhill walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether curcuminoids (with piperine) could reduce systemic inflammatory biomarkers in patients with mild-to-moderate knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: Curcuminoids significantly reduced serum levels of IL-4, IL-6, and hs-CRP but did not affect TNF-α, TGF-β, or ESR. Placebo also showed reductions in some biomarkers, and no significant difference was found between groups in the magnitude of changes.
population_specificity: 40 subjects with mild-to-moderate knee OA
effective_dosage: 1,500 mg/day curcuminoids (divided into 3 doses) + 15 mg/day piperine

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of short-term curcuminoids (with piperine) supplementation in alleviating oxidative stress, clinical symptoms, and improving health-related quality of life in patients with chronic pulmonary complications from sulfur mustard exposure.
results_summary: The curcuminoids-piperine combination significantly increased serum GSH levels, reduced MDA levels, and improved respiratory symptoms and HRQoL scores (SGRQ and CAT) compared to placebo, with statistically significant effects (p < 0.001).
population_specificity: Patients with chronic pulmonary complications (bronchiolitis obliterans) due to sulfur mustard exposure receiving standard respiratory treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective potential and cholesterol-lowering effects of tocotrienols (T(3)), a type of vitamin E, and their bioavailability in humans.
results_summary: Tocotrienols showed potential neuroprotective effects by modulating neuronal cell death pathways and exhibited cholesterol-lowering activity, though human studies were inconsistent. Bioavailability was low but could be enhanced with high-fat meals or specific delivery systems.
population_specificity: Cell cultures, animal models, and some human studies (specific populations not detailed).
effective_dosage: Micromolar concentrations for cholesterol-lowering; ~10 nmol/L for neuronal effects (exact supplementation doses not specified).
interactions: Enhanced bioavailability with high-fat meals; potential inhibition of metabolism/excretion by other phytochemicals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of plant-based diets, which are rich in phytochemicals, on dietary zinc intake and status in humans using systematic review and meta-analysis techniques.
results_summary: The study found that populations following habitual vegetarian diets had significantly lower zinc intakes and serum zinc concentrations compared to non-vegetarians, with greater impacts observed in females, vegans, and those from developing countries. The findings suggest that while plant-based diets are rich in phytochemicals, they may compromise zinc status, necessitating strategies to improve bioavailability or supplementation.
population_specificity: Males and females consuming vegetarian diets, including vegans, compared to non-vegetarian groups, with a focus on populations from both developed and developing countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a phytochemical-rich nutritional supplement, when combined with a hypocaloric diet, could improve metabolic risk parameters in obese women compared to caloric restriction alone.
results_summary: The supplement did not enhance weight loss beyond caloric restriction alone but improved central lipolysis (reduced waist circumference and gynoid fat) and increased HDL-c levels. Both interventions modestly reduced body weight, BMI, and HOMA-IR.
population_specificity: Obese women (BMI 28.72 ± 2.87 kg/m², body fat 40.52 ± 3.75%, age 35.04 ± 5.6 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (consumed as a breakfast substitute).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of resveratrol, alone and in combination with other phytochemicals, on adipogenesis and osteogenesis, particularly in the context of obesity and osteoporosis.
results_summary: Resveratrol reduced adipocyte number and size while increasing osteogenesis. Combinations with genistein, quercetin, and vitamin D showed synergistic effects in preventing weight gain and bone loss in a postmenopausal rat model.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal rat model (in vivo), murine and human adipocytes (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of phytoestrogens on female reproductive health and IVF outcomes, specifically their association with serum estradiol levels, implantation, clinical pregnancy, and live birth rates.
results_summary: Higher concentrations of phytoestrogens in follicular fluid and urine were significantly associated with improved IVF outcomes, including higher serum estradiol, better oocyte maturation, fertilization potential, and increased probabilities of implantation, clinical pregnancy, and live birth.
population_specificity: 60 women undergoing IVF with single frozen euploid blastocyst transfer at IVI-RMA New Jersey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of phytoestrogens as selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) targeting GPERs for breast cancer prevention and treatment.
results_summary: The study suggests that phytoestrogens can interact with GPERs, similar to endogenous estrogens, and may serve as potential dietary supplements for breast cancer prevention and therapy. The mechanisms of GPER pathways were discussed, highlighting their role in novel therapeutic approaches.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on breast cancer prevention and treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether advising against soy consumption (as phytoestrogens) in breast cancer survivors is justified by analyzing its effects on recurrence and mortality.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant adverse effects of soy isoflavones on breast cancer recurrence or mortality, with most studies indicating potential beneficial effects, particularly for post-menopausal women and those with hormone-sensitive cancers.
population_specificity: Women with a history of breast cancer, including both pre- and post-menopausal individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent findings on the interaction between phytoestrogens and gut microbiota and explore their potential future application, particularly in treating breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that phytoestrogens can alter gut microbiota composition and may play a role in reducing estrogen levels, potentially benefiting breast cancer treatment. Probiotics combined with soy phytoestrogens show promise, but more in vivo studies are needed for clinical validation.
population_specificity: Patients with diagnosed breast cancer (particularly women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the bidirectional relationship between postmenopausal osteoporosis and periodontitis and summarize the skeletal effects of phytoestrogens, particularly their alveolar bone protective effects.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens showed potential bone protective effects by inhibiting bone resorption and enhancing bone formation, with promising results in postmenopausal osteoporosis models, though limited studies exist on alveolar bone specifically. Well-designed trials are needed to further investigate their therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with osteoporosis and/or periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of dietary phytoestrogens on ram spermatogenesis, semen quality, and male fertility using a longitudinal sheep model.
results_summary: Phytoestrogen exposure transiently increased sperm midpiece malformations and reduced DNA integrity between 5-8 weeks, with no lasting effects after returning to non-oestrogenic pasture. The seminal plasma proteome showed 93 differentially expressed proteins, primarily affecting sperm structure and DNA integrity pathways.
population_specificity: Merino rams (n = 20)
study_duration: Full spermatogenic cycle and subsequent breeding season

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a targeted delivery system using phytoestrogens (daidzein and genistein) to enhance the efficacy of methionine γ-lyase (MGL) in antitumor therapy.
results_summary: The study demonstrated successful binding of phytoestrogen-decorated nanocapsules to estrogen receptor-positive breast adenocarcinoma cells and showed that MGL-loaded polyionic vesicles (PICsomes) could inhibit early embryonic development in the presence of specific substrates, indicating potential for enzyme therapy in malignant tumors.
population_specificity: ER+ MCF7 breast adenocarcinoma cells and embryos (for developmental impact assessment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of phytoestrogens to target breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) and complement conventional breast cancer therapy.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens were found to target BCSCs by selective estrogen receptor binding and inhibition of molecular pathways used by BCSCs, showing potential to reduce recurrence and improve treatment outcomes. Clinical trial results were also discussed to assess their role in breast cancer treatment and prevention.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients, particularly focusing on BCSCs and postmenopausal women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential neuroprotective effects of phytoestrogens against radiation-induced brain injury and neurodegeneration.
results_summary: The study suggests that phytoestrogens may offer neuroprotection by mitigating oxidative stress, neuroinflammation, and loss of neurogenesis caused by radiation therapy, potentially improving cognitive function in affected patients.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing radiation therapy, particularly those at risk of radiation-induced brain degeneration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chemopreventive and cytoprotective effects of phytoestrogens on prostate cancer progression and their potential role in enhancing chemosensitivity.
results_summary: The study suggests that phytoestrogens, abundant in the Asian diet, may inversely correlate with prostate cancer risk and provide chemoprotective effects. They also enhance chemosensitivity in tumor cells and offer cytoprotection during conventional chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Males at risk of or diagnosed with prostate cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a phytoestrogen-based formula (with vitamin E and grapeseed extract) in reducing menopausal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found a percentage decrease in menopausal symptoms (e.g., irritability, depression, anxiety, hot flashes), with the most significant improvements observed in premenopausal subjects. The formula was deemed beneficial for reducing symptom intensity.
population_specificity: Premenopausal and surgically-induced menopausal women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the estrogenic activity of Pueraria candollei var. mirifica (PM) extract by increasing the aglycone content (daidzein and genistein) using β-glucosidase.
results_summary: The study found that β-glucosidase treatment increased the estrogenic activity of PM extract by 8.71- to 23.2-fold compared to untreated extract, with immobilized β-glucosidase maintaining over 90% efficacy after nine reuses. Optimal conditions for aglycone production were pH 4.8-4.9, temperature 46.3-49.1 °C, and ethanol concentration 10.0-11.0%.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or postmenopausal context implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of phytoestrogens in the prevention and treatment of Alzheimer's disease, despite their classification as endocrine-disrupting chemicals.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens showed beneficial effects on Alzheimer's disease symptoms, including acting as antioxidants, improving visual-spatial memory, reducing amyloid-beta production, and enhancing brain cell growth and plasticity. However, their potential to disrupt hormonal balance was also noted.
population_specificity: Primarily elderly individuals, given the focus on Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding Cimicifuga racemosa (a phytoestrogen) to clomiphene could improve endometrial thickness and follicle number in women with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCO).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in the number of medium, large, or total follicles or in endometrial thickness between the group receiving Cimicifuga racemosa plus clomiphene and the group receiving clomiphene alone.
population_specificity: 100 women with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCO) in Iran.
effective_dosage: Cimicifuga racemosa tablets 10 mg twice a day for 10 days per menstrual cycle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide comprehensive information about the types, sources, and biological actions of phytoestrogens in the reproductive system.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens, structurally similar to human estrogens, show potential health benefits for osteoporosis, heart disease, breast cancer, and prostate cancer, and are used in hormone replacement therapy and dietary supplements. The abstract highlights their growing interest as preventative medicine in nutraceuticals.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the molecular mechanisms, clinical applications, and potential impacts of phytoestrogens in hormone-related cancers.
results_summary: The study reviewed emerging research techniques, molecular mechanisms, and clinical trials, providing evidence-based perspectives on phytoestrogens' role in cancer prevention and treatment. It highlighted the importance of the window of susceptibility (WOS) in environmental estrogen exposure.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of literature and clinical trials from 2002 to present).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of phytoestrogens in treating endometriosis by reviewing in vitro, in vivo, and human studies.
results_summary: In vitro studies showed phytoestrogens had anti-proliferative, anti-inflammatory, and proapoptotic effects. Animal models supported these findings, but human studies were limited and inconclusive.
population_specificity: Cultured cells, animal models of endometriosis, and women with endometriosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between phytoestrogen intake and endometriosis risk, evaluating their potential effects on pathogenesis and therapeutic applications.
results_summary: Favorable results were observed in endometrial primary cultures and animal models for resveratrol, isoflavones, and puerarin, but only resveratrol showed promising results in human intervention trials. Discrepancies in estrogenic/anti-estrogenic effects and interactions with endogenous estrogens were noted.
population_specificity: Women with endometriosis (human trials) and rodent models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether phytoestrogens, as an alternative to estrogen, could provide neuroprotective benefits for Parkinson's disease (PD) while avoiding estrogen's adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that phytoestrogens exhibit neuroprotective activity in PD via interaction with estrogen receptors, particularly ERβ, and may offer benefits similar to estrogen without its harmful side effects, though human studies remain inconclusive.
population_specificity: Animal models and human epidemiological data (no specific human population detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess consumer awareness of phytoestrogens from diet and supplements, as well as their perceived benefits and risks.
results_summary: Most respondents (67.4%) were aware of phytoestrogens, but only 6% believed in their effectiveness. A small group (16.7%) confirmed benefits for menopause symptoms, while half remained uncertain about their efficacy as synthetic drug replacements.
population_specificity: Women (84.5%) and men from diverse age, education, and residential backgrounds in the Silesian Voivodship.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the potential health benefits of phytoestrogens, focusing on their neuroprotective effects and other therapeutic properties.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens were found to lower the risk of menopausal symptoms, osteoporosis, cardiovascular disease, and brain diseases, with neuroprotective effects linked to antioxidant properties and estrogen receptor interaction. They also exhibited antiangiogenic, antimetastatic, and epigenetic effects in cancer, though concerns about thyroid effects were noted.
population_specificity: General population, with implications for menopausal women and individuals at risk for osteoporosis, cardiovascular disease, or brain disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the potential benefits and unresolved issues regarding phytoestrogens as natural alternatives to synthetic estrogens for post-menopausal women and their role in mitigating complications in conditions like type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome, NAFLD, and obesity.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens show promise as estrogen alternatives in reducing complications of menopause and metabolic diseases, but their effectiveness remains inconsistent due to uncertainties about their abundance, gut microbiome conversion, effect thresholds, and synergistic actions. The study identifies key concerns and inconsistencies in existing nutritional and clinical research.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal women and individuals with conditions like type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome, NAFLD, and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of phytoestrogens in treating depression among menopausal women through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens showed a significant positive effect on depressive symptoms in postmenopausal women, particularly at low doses (25–100 mg/day), with isoflavones being more effective than lignans. Mild adverse reactions, such as gastrointestinal symptoms and respiratory infections, were reported.
population_specificity: Menopausal and postmenopausal women.
effective_dosage: Low dose (25–100 mg/day), high dose (>100 mg/day), and ultralow dose (<25 mg/day).
study_duration: Duration of intervention varied, with longer durations showing better efficacy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of phytoestrogens on the treatment of urogenital menopause symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that various forms of phytoestrogens improved urogenital atrophy, urinary disorders, and sexual function in menopausal women, with vaginal use showing greater recovery rates than other methods.
population_specificity: Menopausal women experiencing urogenital symptoms.
effective_dosage: Not specified (various forms including oral capsules, pills, food supplements, enriched powder, vaginal gel, cream, and suppository).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a cereal bar containing phytoestrogens could reduce climacteric symptoms in women.
results_summary: The phytoestrogen group showed significantly greater improvement in climacteric symptoms compared to the placebo group, particularly in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women, with notable reductions in hot flushes, paresthesia, sexual complaints, insomnia, and melancholy.
population_specificity: Women aged 40-65 years with climacteric symptoms from southwestern Paraná, Brazil.
effective_dosage: 80.73 milligrams of soybean and flaxseed phytoestrogens per cereal bar.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of selected phytoestrogens on ANXA1 expression, cell death, and cell cycle arrest in human leukemic cell lines.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens (coumestrol, genistein, estradiol, daidzein) reduced ANXA1 levels, induced apoptosis, and caused cell cycle arrest in leukemic cells. They also promoted phagocytosis, suggesting potential anti-leukemic effects.
population_specificity: Human leukemic cell lines (K562, U937, Jurkat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential benefits and mechanisms of phytoestrogens in treating breast cancer and postmenopausal symptoms.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens show pleiotropic effects on cellular signaling and may benefit estrogen-dependent diseases, though their activation/inhibition of estrogen receptors can disrupt hormone pathways. The abstract suggests potential advantages for breast cancer treatment and postmenopausal symptom prevention.
population_specificity: Women, particularly those with breast cancer or postmenopausal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent evidence on the role of phytoestrogens in cancer prevention and their impact on cancer therapy efficacy.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens exhibit antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anti-thrombotic, anti-allergic, and anti-tumoral properties, with documented roles in cancer prevention. However, their impact on treatment efficiency is controversial, as they may interfere with anti-cancer drugs while potentially protecting healthy cells from treatment side effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing research).
interactions: Potential interference with anti-cancer drugs mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent literature on the effects of phytoestrogens, particularly focusing on their benefits and safety for postreproductive health, including menopause-related conditions.
results_summary: Phytoestrogens showed a small, slow reduction in vasomotor symptoms of menopause and potential benefits for bone mineral density and cardiovascular risk markers, though evidence was heterogeneous. No harmful effects on breast, endometrial, or colorectal cancers were found, and some protective effects were noted. Cognitive effects were mixed, with most studies showing no significant association.
population_specificity: Postreproductive individuals, particularly those experiencing menopause-related conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of phytoestrogens in treating Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) by examining their mechanisms of action and comparing them to synthetic drugs.
